<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [21]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython2"><pre><span></span><span class="c1">#Data Structures - Gets more interesting now :)</span>

<span class="c1">#Lists - List are enclosed in the square bracket []</span>
<span class="n">shoplist</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'apple'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'mango'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'carrot'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'banana'</span><span class="p">]</span>
<span class="k">print</span> <span class="s1">'I have {} items to purchase'</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">format</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nb">len</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">shoplist</span><span class="p">))</span>
<span class="k">print</span> <span class="s1">'</span><span class="se">\n</span><span class="s1">The items I need to purchase are: '</span>
<span class="k">for</span> <span class="n">item</span> <span class="ow">in</span> <span class="n">shoplist</span><span class="p">:</span>
    <span class="k">print</span> <span class="n">item</span><span class="p">,</span>
    
<span class="c1">#Appending the item rice</span>
<span class="n">shoplist</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">append</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'rice'</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="k">print</span> <span class="s1">'</span><span class="se">\n\n</span><span class="s1">The modified list of items: '</span>
<span class="k">for</span> <span class="n">item</span> <span class="ow">in</span> <span class="n">shoplist</span><span class="p">:</span>
    <span class="k">print</span> <span class="n">item</span><span class="p">,</span>
    
<span class="n">shoplist</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">sort</span><span class="p">()</span>
<span class="k">print</span> <span class="s1">'</span><span class="se">\n\n</span><span class="s1"> The sorted shopping list'</span>
<span class="k">for</span> <span class="n">item</span> <span class="ow">in</span> <span class="n">shoplist</span><span class="p">:</span>
    <span class="k">print</span> <span class="n">item</span><span class="p">,</span>
    
<span class="k">print</span> <span class="s1">'</span><span class="se">\n\n</span><span class="s1">The first item I will buy is'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">shoplist</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">]</span>
<span class="k">del</span> <span class="n">shoplist</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">]</span>
<span class="k">for</span> <span class="n">item</span> <span class="ow">in</span> <span class="n">shoplist</span><span class="p">:</span>
    <span class="k">print</span> <span class="n">item</span><span class="p">,</span>
</pre></div>

</div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area"><div class="prompt"></div>
<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>I have 4 items to purchase

The items I need to purchase are: 
apple mango carrot banana 

The modified list of items: 
apple mango carrot banana rice 

 The sorted shopping list
apple banana carrot mango rice 

The first item I will buy is apple
banana carrot mango rice
</pre>
</div>
</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [22]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython2"><pre><span></span><span class="c1">#Understanding iterables and iterators - Look into it only if you are interested</span>
<span class="c1"># http://www.shutupandship.com/2012/01/understanding-python-iterables-and.html</span>
</pre></div>

</div>
</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [30]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython2"><pre><span></span><span class="c1">#Tuple</span>

<span class="c1">#Tuples are used to hold together multiple objects. Think of them similar to list</span>
<span class="c1">#but without the extensive functionality that the list class gives. One major </span>
<span class="c1">#feature of tuples is that they are immutable like strings i.e., you cannot </span>
<span class="c1">#modify tuples</span>

<span class="n">zoo</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'python'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'elephant'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'penguin'</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="k">print</span> <span class="s1">'Number of animals in the zoo is'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="nb">len</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">zoo</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="n">new_zoo</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s1">'monkey'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'camel'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">zoo</span>
<span class="k">print</span> <span class="s1">'Number of animals in the zoo is'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="nb">len</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">new_zoo</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="k">print</span> <span class="s1">'All the animals in the new zoo are'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">new_zoo</span>
<span class="k">print</span> <span class="s1">'All the animals brought from old zoo are'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">new_zoo</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="mi">2</span><span class="p">]</span>
<span class="k">print</span> <span class="s1">'Last animal brought from the old zoo are'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">new_zoo</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="mi">2</span><span class="p">][</span><span class="mi">2</span><span class="p">]</span>

<span class="k">print</span> <span class="s1">'Number of animals in the new zoo is'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="nb">len</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">new_zoo</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="o">+</span><span class="nb">len</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">new_zoo</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="mi">2</span><span class="p">])</span>
</pre></div>

</div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area"><div class="prompt"></div>
<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>Number of animals in the zoo is 3
Number of animals in the zoo is 3
All the animals in the new zoo are ('monkey', 'camel', ('python', 'elephant', 'penguin'))
All the animals brought from old zoo are ('python', 'elephant', 'penguin')
Last animal brought from the old zoo are penguin
Number of animals in the new zoo is 5
</pre>
</div>
</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [37]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython2"><pre><span></span><span class="c1">#Empty tuple</span>
<span class="n">myempty</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">()</span>
<span class="k">print</span> <span class="n">myempty</span>

<span class="n">singleton</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="k">print</span> <span class="nb">type</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">singleton</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="n">singleton</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">,)</span>
<span class="k">print</span> <span class="nb">type</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">singleton</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>

</div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area"><div class="prompt"></div>
<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>()
<type 'int'>
<type 'tuple'>
</pre>
</div>
</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [49]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython2"><pre><span></span><span class="c1">#Dictionary</span>

<span class="c1">#A dictionary is like a address book, you can find the address or contact </span>
<span class="c1">#details of a person by knowing only his/her name i.e., we associate keys with</span>
<span class="c1">#values. </span>

<span class="c1">#Note that key must be unique just like we cannot find out the correct </span>
<span class="c1">#information if you have two persons with exact same name</span>

<span class="n">ab</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">{</span><span class="s1">'nrupatunga'</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="s1">'nrupatunga@gmail.com'</span><span class="p">,</span> 
        <span class="s1">'Larry'</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="s1">'larry@wall.org'</span><span class="p">,</span> 
        <span class="s1">'Matsumoto'</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="s1">'matz@ruby-lang.com'</span><span class="p">,</span> 
         <span class="s1">'Spammer'</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="s1">'spammer@hotmail.com'</span><span class="p">}</span>
<span class="k">print</span> <span class="nb">type</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">ab</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="k">print</span> <span class="s2">"Nrupatunga's address is"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">ab</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'nrupatunga'</span><span class="p">]</span>
<span class="k">for</span> <span class="n">name</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">address</span> <span class="ow">in</span> <span class="n">ab</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">iteritems</span><span class="p">():</span><span class="c1">#itemitems are the efficient implementation of method items()</span>
    <span class="k">print</span> <span class="s1">'contact {} at {}'</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">format</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">name</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">address</span><span class="p">)</span>
    
<span class="k">del</span> <span class="n">ab</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'Spammer'</span><span class="p">]</span>

<span class="k">print</span> <span class="s1">'</span><span class="se">\n\n</span><span class="s1">'</span>

<span class="k">for</span> <span class="n">name</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">address</span> <span class="ow">in</span> <span class="n">ab</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">iteritems</span><span class="p">():</span>
    <span class="k">print</span> <span class="s1">'contact {} at {}'</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">format</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">name</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">address</span><span class="p">)</span>

    
</pre></div>

</div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area"><div class="prompt"></div>
<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre><type 'dict'>
Nrupatunga's address is nrupatunga@gmail.com
contact Matsumoto at matz@ruby-lang.com
contact Larry at larry@wall.org
contact Spammer at spammer@hotmail.com
contact nrupatunga at nrupatunga@gmail.com



contact Matsumoto at matz@ruby-lang.com
contact Larry at larry@wall.org
contact nrupatunga at nrupatunga@gmail.com
</pre>
</div>
</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [1]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython2"><pre><span></span><span class="c1">#Sequence</span>
<span class="c1">#Lists, tuples and strings are examples of sequences, but what are sequences</span>
<span class="c1"># and what's special about them</span>

<span class="c1">#The major features are membership tests, i.e., the 'in' and 'not in' </span>
<span class="c1"># expressions and the indexing operations, which allows us to retrieve a slice </span>
<span class="c1"># of sequence i.e., a part of the sequence</span>

<span class="n">shoplist</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'apple'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'mango'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'carrot'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'banana'</span><span class="p">]</span>
<span class="n">name</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s1">'nrupatunga'</span>

<span class="k">print</span> <span class="s1">'item 0 is'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">shoplist</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">]</span>
<span class="k">print</span> <span class="s1">'item -1 is'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">shoplist</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">]</span> 
<span class="k">print</span> <span class="s1">'item -2 is'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">shoplist</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="mi">2</span><span class="p">]</span>

<span class="k">print</span> <span class="s1">'item start to end'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">shoplist</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">]</span>
<span class="k">print</span> <span class="s1">'item start to end'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">shoplist</span><span class="p">[:]</span>

<span class="k">print</span> <span class="n">name</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">:]</span>
<span class="k">print</span> <span class="n">name</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="mi">5</span><span class="p">]</span>
</pre></div>

</div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area"><div class="prompt"></div>
<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>item 0 is apple
item -1 is banana
item -2 is carrot
item start to end ['apple', 'mango', 'carrot']
item start to end ['apple', 'mango', 'carrot', 'banana']
nrupatunga
nrupa
</pre>
</div>
</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [73]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython2"><pre><span></span><span class="c1">#We can also provide a third argument for the slice which is the step for the </span>
<span class="c1">#slicing </span>

<span class="n">shoplist</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'apple'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'mango'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'carrot'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'banana'</span><span class="p">]</span>
<span class="n">shoplist</span><span class="p">[::</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="mi">2</span><span class="p">]</span>
</pre></div>

</div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area"><div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[73]:</div>


<div class="output_text output_subarea output_execute_result">
<pre>['banana', 'mango']</pre>
</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [80]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython2"><pre><span></span><span class="c1">#Set</span>

<span class="c1">#Sets are unordered collections of simple objects. These are used when the </span>
<span class="c1">#existence of an object in a collection is more important than the order or how </span>
<span class="c1">#many times it occurs</span>

<span class="n">bri</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nb">set</span><span class="p">([</span><span class="s1">'brazil'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'russia'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'india'</span><span class="p">])</span>

<span class="k">print</span> <span class="s1">'india'</span> <span class="ow">in</span> <span class="n">bri</span>
<span class="k">print</span> <span class="s1">'usa'</span> <span class="ow">in</span> <span class="n">bri</span>
<span class="n">bric</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">bri</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">copy</span><span class="p">()</span>
<span class="n">bric</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">add</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'china'</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="k">print</span> <span class="n">bric</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">issuperset</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">bri</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">bri</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">remove</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'russia'</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">bri</span> <span class="o">&</span> <span class="n">bric</span>
</pre></div>

</div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area"><div class="prompt"></div>
<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>True
False
True
</pre>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_area"><div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[80]:</div>


<div class="output_text output_subarea output_execute_result">
<pre>{'brazil', 'india'}</pre>
</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [85]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython2"><pre><span></span><span class="c1">#References</span>

<span class="k">print</span> <span class="s1">'Simple assignment'</span>
<span class="n">shoplist</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'apple'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'mango'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'carrot'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'banana'</span><span class="p">]</span>
<span class="n">mylist</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">shoplist</span> <span class="c1">#points to the same object</span>

<span class="k">del</span> <span class="n">shoplist</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">]</span>
<span class="k">print</span> <span class="n">shoplist</span>
<span class="k">print</span> <span class="n">mylist</span>

<span class="n">mylist</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">shoplist</span><span class="p">[:]</span> <span class="c1">#slicing create a new object type mylist of type list</span>

<span class="k">del</span> <span class="n">shoplist</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">]</span>
<span class="k">print</span> <span class="n">shoplist</span>
<span class="k">print</span> <span class="n">mylist</span>
</pre></div>

</div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area"><div class="prompt"></div>
<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>Simple assignment
['mango', 'carrot', 'banana']
['mango', 'carrot', 'banana']
['carrot', 'banana']
['mango', 'carrot', 'banana']
</pre>
</div>
</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [99]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython2"><pre><span></span><span class="c1">#More about strings</span>

<span class="c1">#Strings are also objects and have methods which do everything from checking </span>
<span class="c1">#part of a string to stripping string</span>

<span class="c1">#The strings which we use in the program are all objects of the class 'str'</span>

<span class="n">name</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s1">'Nrupatunga'</span>
<span class="k">if</span> <span class="n">name</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">startswith</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'Nrup'</span><span class="p">):</span>
    <span class="k">print</span> <span class="s1">'yes it starts with "Nrup"'</span>

<span class="k">if</span> <span class="s1">'a'</span> <span class="ow">in</span> <span class="n">name</span><span class="p">:</span>
    <span class="k">print</span> <span class="s1">'yes, it contains the string "a"'</span>

<span class="k">if</span> <span class="n">name</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">find</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'tunga'</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="o">!=</span> <span class="o">-</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">:</span>
    <span class="k">print</span> <span class="s1">'Yes it contains the word "tunga"'</span>
    
<span class="n">mylist</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'Andrew'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'YaanLecun'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'Yoshua'</span><span class="p">]</span>
<span class="n">delimiter</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s1">' '</span> <span class="c1">#Note how this works, it nice know!</span>
<span class="k">print</span> <span class="n">delimiter</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">join</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">mylist</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>

</div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area"><div class="prompt"></div>
<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>yes it starts with "Nrup"
yes, it contains the string "a"
Yes it contains the word "tunga"
Andrew YaanLecun Yoshua
</pre>
</div>
</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [ ]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython2"><pre><span></span><span class="c1">#Continued in Part-2</span>
</pre></div>

</div>
</div>
</div>

</div>
    </div>
  </div>
</body>
</html>

item.title: Linear Algebra Part 1
item.description:
This is the summary of the topics covered by Gilbert Strang in his lectures

Table of Contents:

  • Lectures 1-5
  • Lectures 6-10
  • Lectures 11-15

Lectures 1-5

Covers the basic matrix concepts

  • Matrix Row picture and Column picture
  • Can we solve for \(Ax=b\) for all \(b\) ?. No, only for \(b\)’s in the column space of \(A\).

Four ways of matrix multiplication

  • Dot product
  • Column picture
  • Row picture
  • Column times Row

Gaussian Elimination

  • Operates on the rows of matrix \(A\), finally puts the matrix in Row Reduced Echelon(REF) form
  • Gaussian elimination leads to \(A = LU\) form, and \(A = LDU\) form

Gauss-Jordon form

  • Helps to put the elements of \(A\), in the Row Reduced Echelon Form (RREF) form
  • Can be used to solve for \(x\) in \(Ax = b\), by finding **_RREF([\(A\) \(b\)])** which results in **[\(I\) \(x\)]_**
  • Can be used to find the inverse of the matrix \(A\) by finding **_RREF[\(A\) \(I\)]** which results in **[\(I\) \(A^{-1}\)]_**

Permutation matrix

  • Number of permutation matrix \(A_{N*N} = N!\)
  • \(P^T = P\) (where \(P^T\) is transpose(\(P\)))
  • \(P P^T = I\) (Can you prove? Hint: use definition of matrix multiplication) * If the number of equations are less than number of variables, why we cannot solve the equation? * This is because rank of the matrix will be less than the number of variables we need to solve, so it will have infinite number of solutions * Use RREF(\(A\)) in matlab/octave and check
  • \(A A^T\) is symmetric, prove!

Lectures 6-10

Vector Space

  • All linear combination of vectors are in the space, called Vector Space

  • Say \(P\) and \(L\) are two subspaces

    • Is \(P\cup L\) a subspace? No, because some combination of vector \(A \in P\) and vector \(B \in L\) might not be in the subspace \(P\cup L\).

Column Space and Null Space

  • Column Space C(\(A\)) is all possible linear combinations of column vectors in a matrix \(A\)

  • Null Space N(\(A\)) is all the \(x\)’s for which \(Ax = 0\)

  • Elimination process will change Column Space of \(A\), but not the Null space of \(A\)

    • This is because in the elimination process we change \(A\), but not \(x\).

Basic and Free Variables

  • The real difference between basic variables and free variables is that the free variables can be anything, and the basic variables are determined by solving the equations

  • Basic variables are also called as Pivot variables. The columns with these variables are called Pivot columns

  • Number of Pivot columns = Rank r of the matrix = Number of independent columns in the matrix

  • Number of Free columns = n - r ( n = number of columns in matrix \(A))

Solution for Ax = b

Rank tells you everything about the number of solutions

  • Full column rank matrix: Unique solution exists, if \(b\) lies in column space of \(A\)
  • Full row rank matrix: Infinite number of solutions
  • Full row rank/ full column rank: Unique solution always exists for all \(b\)
  • No full column rank/ No full row rank: Infinitely many solution exists if \(b\) lies in column space of \(A\)

Basis

  • Basis of a vector space is sequence of vectors \(v_1, v_2, v_3, …, v_N\) with the following properties
    • They are independent
    • They span a space

Four Subspaces

For a matrix \(A_{m*n}\)

  • Column space C(\(A\)): combination of columns of \(A\), lies in \(R^n\)
  • Null space N(\(A^T\)) : left null space of \(A\), lies in \(R^n\)
  • Row space R(\(A\)): combination of columns of \(A^T\), lies in \(R^m\)
  • Null space N(\(A\)): right null space of \(A\), lies in \(R^m\)
  • Row operation on a matrix \(A\) changes the column space of \(A\), but preserves the row space of \(A\)

## Lectures 11-15

Vector Space of Matrices

  • Consider vector space of matrices \(A_{N*N}\)
    • Dimension of vector space of symmetric matrices = \((N^2 + N)/2\)
    • Dimension of vector space of skew symmetric matrices = \((N^2 - N)/2\)
    • Dimension of vector space of upper triangular matrices = \((N^2 + N)/2\)
    • (Symmetric matrix \(\cap\) Upper triangular matrices) = Diagonal matrices. Dimension of vector space = \((N^2 - N)/2\)
    • (Symmetric matrix \(\cup\) Upper triangular matrices) = All \(N*N\) matrices. Dimension of vector space = \(N^2\)

Rank-1 Matrices

  • They are special case
  • They are building blocks for every other matrices
  • Matrices with Rank-1 are separable matrices ( this is the application in image processing for separating the filters)

Orthogonality

  • Prove that two vectors \(X\) and \(Y\) are orthogonal to each other if \(X^T Y = 0 = Y^T X\)
  • Row space is perpendicular to Right null space , i.e., every vector in row space is perpendicular to every other vector in right null space
  • Column space is perpendicular to left null space, i.e., every vector in column space is perpendicular to every other vector in left null space

Projection Matrix

  • Projection of vector \(b\) onto vector \(a\) is defined as \(p = Pb\), where \(P = (a a^T)/(a^T a) \)

  • Column space of projection matrix \(P\) is column space of \(a\). i.e., line through \(a\)
  • Properties of Projection matrices
    • \(P^T = P\)
    • \(P^2 = P\)
  • Projection matrix in general
    • We have \(A^T A \hat{x} = A^T B\)
    • \(P = A \hat{x}\), where \(\hat{x} = (A^T A)^{-1} A^T B\) and \(P = A (A^T A)^{-1} A^T \)

Least square problem

  • Why projection ?
    • When we have only few unknowns, but many equations to solve \(Ax = b\), \(b\) might not be the column space of \(A\)
    • To solve for \(x\), we project \(b\) onto columns space of \(A\), so that the new vector \(\bar{b}\) is closest to \(b\)
      • Eg. Measuring pulse of the heart, but repeatedly we take measurements so that on an average we can estimate the pulse. For more detailed treatment of least squares, link
  • The pictorial representation of solving least squares is shown below
    • Least squares: \(\bar{x}\) minimizes \(b - Ax\) by solving \(A^T A \bar{x} = A^T b\)

  • \(A^T A\) is invertible, if \(A\) has independent columns, prove it
